values.description:
This pull request expands the existing `ignition::common` plugin framework to accomplish three major goals:

1. Allow multiple plugins per library
2. Allow multiple interfaces per plugin
3. Squash some subtle bugs in the implementation of plugins

Unfortunately, this PR pretty much clobbers backwards compatibility with any plugins that were created using the older framework. I made some earnest attempts to allow robust backwards compatibility, but the prior implementation had bugs (mostly pertaining to plugin destruction) that cannot be resolved except by rebuilding the shared libraries of those plugins with these new changes. The current attempt at backwards compatibility introduces memory leaks that will cause the plugin instances to remain in existence until the executable exits.

This also completely clobbers the API for using the plugins once they are loaded. This clobbering also relates to the fact that the prior implementation had subtle destruction bugs.

Given all these issues, I would recommend we purge out the backwards compatibility entirely and just require all plugin users to adopt the new API and ABI (which should be a relatively painless transition, since all use of these plugins is currently internal).
values.title: Expand the functionality of the plugin framework

summary.raw:
This pull request expands the existing `ignition::common` plugin framework to accomplish three major goals:

1. Allow multiple plugins per library
2. Allow multiple interfaces per plugin
3. Squash some subtle bugs in the implementation of plugins

Unfortunately, this PR pretty much clobbers backwards compatibility with any plugins that were created using the older framework. I made some earnest attempts to allow robust backwards compatibility, but the prior implementation had bugs (mostly pertaining to plugin destruction) that cannot be resolved except by rebuilding the shared libraries of those plugins with these new changes. The current attempt at backwards compatibility introduces memory leaks that will cause the plugin instances to remain in existence until the executable exits.

This also completely clobbers the API for using the plugins once they are loaded. This clobbering also relates to the fact that the prior implementation had subtle destruction bugs.

Given all these issues, I would recommend we purge out the backwards compatibility entirely and just require all plugin users to adopt the new API and ABI (which should be a relatively painless transition, since all use of these plugins is currently internal).
summary.html:
This pull request expands the existing ignition::common plugin framework to accomplish three major goals:

  1. Allow multiple plugins per library
  2. Allow multiple interfaces per plugin
  3. Squash some subtle bugs in the implementation of plugins

Unfortunately, this PR pretty much clobbers backwards compatibility with any plugins that were created using the older framework. I made some earnest attempts to allow robust backwards compatibility, but the prior implementation had bugs (mostly pertaining to plugin destruction) that cannot be resolved except by rebuilding the shared libraries of those plugins with these new changes. The current attempt at backwards compatibility introduces memory leaks that will cause the plugin instances to remain in existence until the executable exits.

This also completely clobbers the API for using the plugins once they are loaded. This clobbering also relates to the fact that the prior implementation had subtle destruction bugs.

Given all these issues, I would recommend we purge out the backwards compatibility entirely and just require all plugin users to adopt the new API and ABI (which should be a relatively painless transition, since all use of these plugins is currently internal).

I'm particularly interested in [this](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/optional).

values.description: It was found that the worker pool unit test has a tendency to produce false negatives, depending on the environment that it's being run in. These changes aim to reduce the likelihood of those false negatives (although they can still occur) without violating the intention of the test.
values.title: Making the worker pool unit test a little less flaky

summary.raw: It was found that the worker pool unit test has a tendency to produce false negatives, depending on the environment that it's being run in. These changes aim to reduce the likelihood of those false negatives (although they can still occur) without violating the intention of the test.

values.description:
This is related to issue #14 and trying to make ign-common more modular and the principle of don't-pay-for-what-you-don't-use.

The optional dependencies were removed from pipelines to demonstrate that it still builds. We should put them back before merging this.

values.description:
The previous pull request which expanded the plugin framework has been closed and replaced with this one, because much of the implementation performed in the prior PR has been nearly rewritten here. This PR still serves the same purpose:

1. Allow multiple plugins per library
2. Allow multiple interfaces per plugin
3. Squash some subtle bugs in the implementation of plugins

Additionally it comes with some new semantics for plugin usage and management:

1. Instances of plugins are managed by a `PluginPtr` which is able to behave like a `std::shared_ptr` if desired.
2. You can define `SpecializedPluginPtr` objects which provide extremely low-cost access to the interfaces that are provided by a plugin instance (as long as you can anticipate the existence of those interfaces at compile time).
3. `PluginPtr` objects can be "cast" to `SpecializedPluginPtr` objects (thanks to the `std::shared_ptr`-esque behavior) and different types of `SpecializedPluginPtr`s can be "cast" between each other.

This pull request also eliminates backwards compatibility with the earlier version of the plugin framework because the backwards compatibility was seen as unnecessarily burdensome since this version has not been released yet. After this has been released, we will be able to implement reasonable backwards compatibility measures for any future changes to the API or ABI.
values.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

3. Squash some subtle bugs in the implementation of plugins

Additionally it comes with some new semantics for plugin usage and management:

1. Instances of plugins are managed by a `PluginPtr` which is able to behave like a `std::shared_ptr` if desired.
2. You can define `SpecializedPluginPtr` objects which provide extremely low-cost access to the interfaces that are provided by a plugin instance (as long as you can anticipate the existence of those interfaces at compile time).
3. `PluginPtr` objects can be "cast" to `SpecializedPluginPtr` objects (thanks to the `std::shared_ptr`-esque behavior) and different types of `SpecializedPluginPtr`s can be "cast" between each other.

This pull request also eliminates backwards compatibility with the earlier version of the plugin framework because the backwards compatibility was seen as unnecessarily burdensome since this version has not been released yet. After this has been released, we will be able to implement reasonable backwards compatibility measures for any future changes to the API or ABI.
summary.html:
The previous pull request which expanded the plugin framework has been closed and replaced with this one, because much of the implementation performed in the prior PR has been nearly rewritten here. This PR still serves the same purpose:

  1. Allow multiple plugins per library
  2. Allow multiple interfaces per plugin
  3. Squash some subtle bugs in the implementation of plugins

Additionally it comes with some new semantics for plugin usage and management:

  1. Instances of plugins are managed by a PluginPtr which is able to behave like a std::shared_ptr if desired.
  2. You can define SpecializedPluginPtr objects which provide extremely low-cost access to the interfaces that are provided by a plugin instance (as long as you can anticipate the existence of those interfaces at compile time).
  3. PluginPtr objects can be "cast" to SpecializedPluginPtr objects (thanks to the std::shared_ptr-esque behavior) and different types of SpecializedPluginPtrs can be "cast" between each other.

This pull request also eliminates backwards compatibility with the earlier version of the plugin framework because the backwards compatibility was seen as unnecessarily burdensome since this version has not been released yet. After this has been released, we will be able to implement reasonable backwards compatibility measures for any future changes to the API or ABI.

values.description: Prior to this PR, when outputting to ignmsg or igndbg (basically, one of the std::cout streams), no output would be printed until much later (often until the program quitted).  This happened despite the fact that std::ios_base::unitbuf was set on all of the streams.  The reason for this is simple; Logger::Buffer::sync() output any trailing newline in the wrong position due to the color handling.  That is, the original output buffer got stored, but the last thing to be sent out to std::cout was always a color-end escape sequence, not a carriage return.  To remedy this, this PR looks into the buffer prior to outputting it, and if the last character is \n, it outputs an additional \n on the end.  Note that I believe this works on Windows and Unixen, though I have only tested that it works properly on Linux.
values.title: Add a trailing newline if necessary.

summary.raw: Prior to this PR, when outputting to ignmsg or igndbg (basically, one of the std::cout streams), no output would be printed until much later (often until the program quitted).  This happened despite the fact that std::ios_base::unitbuf was set on all of the streams.  The reason for this is simple; Logger::Buffer::sync() output any trailing newline in the wrong position due to the color handling.  That is, the original output buffer got stored, but the last thing to be sent out to std::cout was always a color-end escape sequence, not a carriage return.  To remedy this, this PR looks into the buffer prior to outputting it, and if the last character is \n, it outputs an additional \n on the end.  Note that I believe this works on Windows and Unixen, though I have only tested that it works properly on Linux.
summary.html: Prior to this PR, when outputting to ignmsg or igndbg (basically, one of the std::cout streams), no output would be printed until much later (often until the program quitted). This happened despite the fact that std::ios_base::unitbuf was set on all of the streams. The reason for this is simple; Logger::Buffer::sync() output any trailing newline in the wrong position due to the color handling. That is, the original output buffer got stored, but the last thing to be sent out to std::cout was always a color-end escape sequence, not a carriage return. To remedy this, this PR looks into the buffer prior to outputting it, and if the last character is \n, it outputs an additional \n on the end. Note that I believe this works on Windows and Unixen, though I have only tested that it works properly on Linux.

values.description:
This pull request is being redirected towards pull request #73 which is a simplified version of this PR.

In this PR, we introduce template specializations which eliminate the overhead of the generic `Plugin` class, and we also introduce the `PluginPtr` class which is (unfortunately) needed in order to support the template specializations.

Hopefully this PR might be less tedious for reviewers after they have looked over pull request #73. The features introduced specifically in this PR are

1. The `Plugin` object can be specialized at compile time to give direct access to any interfaces that can be anticipated ahead of time.

2.  You can cast between different `Plugin` specializations at a one-time map construction cost.
values.title: Expanding the functionality of the plugin framework, and introducing PluginPtr and specializations

summary.raw:
This pull request is being redirected towards pull request #73 which is a simplified version of this PR.

In this PR, we introduce template specializations which eliminate the overhead of the generic `Plugin` class, and we also introduce the `PluginPtr` class which is (unfortunately) needed in order to support the template specializations.

Hopefully this PR might be less tedious for reviewers after they have looked over pull request #73. The features introduced specifically in this PR are

1. The `Plugin` object can be specialized at compile time to give direct access to any interfaces that can be anticipated ahead of time.

2.  You can cast between different `Plugin` specializations at a one-time map construction cost.
summary.html:
This pull request is being redirected towards pull request #73 which is a simplified version of this PR.

In this PR, we introduce template specializations which eliminate the overhead of the generic Plugin class, and we also introduce the PluginPtr class which is (unfortunately) needed in order to support the template specializations.

Hopefully this PR might be less tedious for reviewers after they have looked over pull request #73. The features introduced specifically in this PR are

  1. The Plugin object can be specialized at compile time to give direct access to any interfaces that can be anticipated ahead of time.

  2. You can cast between different Plugin specializations at a one-time map construction cost.

values.description:
This fixes issue #20

My solution is to direct all logging output into a directory called `tmp-ign` and then delete `tmp-ign` at the end of each set of tests that use it. Most of the tests use the `AutoLogFixture`, so putting the cleanup in that class's destructor solved most of the problem cases.

I decided to make the `tmp-ign` a visible directory (as opposed to making it something like `.tmp-ign`) to make it more noticeable for us to debug or cleanup if it fails to be removed at the end of any tests.
values.title: Cleanup log directories after tests are run

summary.raw:
This fixes issue #20

My solution is to direct all logging output into a directory called `tmp-ign` and then delete `tmp-ign` at the end of each set of tests that use it. Most of the tests use the `AutoLogFixture`, so putting the cleanup in that class's destructor solved most of the problem cases.

I decided to make the `tmp-ign` a visible directory (as opposed to making it something like `.tmp-ign`) to make it more noticeable for us to debug or cleanup if it fails to be removed at the end of any tests.
summary.html:
This fixes issue #20

My solution is to direct all logging output into a directory called tmp-ign and then delete tmp-ign at the end of each set of tests that use it. Most of the tests use the AutoLogFixture, so putting the cleanup in that class's destructor solved most of the problem cases.

I decided to make the tmp-ign a visible directory (as opposed to making it something like .tmp-ign) to make it more noticeable for us to debug or cleanup if it fails to be removed at the end of any tests.

values.description:
~~This should be my very last PR related to plugin features. After this change, the plugin framework will have 100% of the features and safeties that I was hoping for.~~ I was wrong, see [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/98/).

Note that this PR is meant to be reviewed after pull request #59 is merged; this is not meant to replace it. If you do review this PR before pull request #59 is merged, then I recommend only looking at commit 7510fd1 because that will show the diff between the two.

The purpose of this PR is to ensure that dynamically linked libraries are able to unload when they are no longer being used. Without these changes, any library that gets loaded by the `PluginLoader` will remain loaded throughout the remaining lifespan of the executable. I view this is a potential source of "memory leaking", because the shared library will take up space in the system memory even if all the plugins which were using it have been deleted. If a user wanted to hotswap between a bunch of different implementations of some interface where each implementation is provided by a different shared library, those shared libraries would begin to pile up for as long as the program is running, even if the library is no longer being used or referenced.

With the changes here, we are able to track whether any plugins (or `PluginLoader`s) are referencing the shared libraries which have been loaded. When all references for a library have dropped to zero, the library is instructed to unload using `dlclose`. (Note that instructing the shared library to unload does not guarantee that it will actually unload, because it is up to the operating system to decide if it will actually bother doing so.)

Note that there is one fragile aspect of this implementation: The ordering of some of the member variables in the class definitions for `PluginWithDlHandle` (which is a new class in this PR) and in `PluginLoaderPrivate` are very important, because they need to be destructed in the correct order. This importance is very strongly noted in the inline documentation for those classes, and I've written a sequence of tests which will fail spectacularly if this ordering is violated, so we shouldn't have to worry much. Just know that if you innocently modify those class definitions and the tests start to fail on you in surprising ways, it's probably because you inadvertently reordered those member variables.
values.title: Automatically unloading libraries when they are no longer being referenced

summary.html:
This should be my very last PR related to plugin features. After this change, the plugin framework will have 100% of the features and safeties that I was hoping for. I was wrong, see here.

Note that this PR is meant to be reviewed after pull request #59 is merged; this is not meant to replace it. If you do review this PR before pull request #59 is merged, then I recommend only looking at commit 7510fd1 because that will show the diff between the two.

The purpose of this PR is to ensure that dynamically linked libraries are able to unload when they are no longer being used. Without these changes, any library that gets loaded by the PluginLoader will remain loaded throughout the remaining lifespan of the executable. I view this is a potential source of "memory leaking", because the shared library will take up space in the system memory even if all the plugins which were using it have been deleted. If a user wanted to hotswap between a bunch of different implementations of some interface where each implementation is provided by a different shared library, those shared libraries would begin to pile up for as long as the program is running, even if the library is no longer being used or referenced.

With the changes here, we are able to track whether any plugins (or PluginLoaders) are referencing the shared libraries which have been loaded. When all references for a library have dropped to zero, the library is instructed to unload using dlclose. (Note that instructing the shared library to unload does not guarantee that it will actually unload, because it is up to the operating system to decide if it will actually bother doing so.)

Note that there is one fragile aspect of this implementation: The ordering of some of the member variables in the class definitions for PluginWithDlHandle (which is a new class in this PR) and in PluginLoaderPrivate are very important, because they need to be destructed in the correct order. This importance is very strongly noted in the inline documentation for those classes, and I've written a sequence of tests which will fail spectacularly if this ordering is violated, so we shouldn't have to worry much. Just know that if you innocently modify those class definitions and the tests start to fail on you in surprising ways, it's probably because you inadvertently reordered those member variables.

values.description:
~~This PR fixes a `std::tolower` compilation issue that has been popping up on the Windows CI ([see bottom](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/ignition_common-ci-default-windows7-amd64/lastFailedBuild/console)).~~

~~However, it is still producing a compilation error which complains about not being able to link to the dl library ([see bottom](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/250/console)). In this PR, I tried also explicitly adding dl to the libraries that get linked against, but that did not solve this linking issue. I'm setting up a virtual machine to run Windows so I can examine this further, but in the meantime, this PR at least fixes the `std::tolower` issue.~~

Edit: To better facilitate fixing these issues, I created a Windows environment and did some debugging with Visual Studio 2017. In the process, I found numerous issues with trying to build and run on Windows, so now the latest image of this pull request reflects numerous fixes that were necessary in order to compile `ignition-common` on Windows and successfully run its tests.
values.title: Fixing Windows Issues

summary.raw:
~~This PR fixes a `std::tolower` compilation issue that has been popping up on the Windows CI ([see bottom](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/ignition_common-ci-default-windows7-amd64/lastFailedBuild/console)).~~

~~However, it is still producing a compilation error which complains about not being able to link to the dl library ([see bottom](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/250/console)). In this PR, I tried also explicitly adding dl to the libraries that get linked against, but that did not solve this linking issue. I'm setting up a virtual machine to run Windows so I can examine this further, but in the meantime, this PR at least fixes the `std::tolower` issue.~~

Edit: To better facilitate fixing these issues, I created a Windows environment and did some debugging with Visual Studio 2017. In the process, I found numerous issues with trying to build and run on Windows, so now the latest image of this pull request reflects numerous fixes that were necessary in order to compile `ignition-common` on Windows and successfully run its tests.
summary.html:
This PR fixes a std::tolower compilation issue that has been popping up on the Windows CI (see bottom).

However, it is still producing a compilation error which complains about not being able to link to the dl library (see bottom). In this PR, I tried also explicitly adding dl to the libraries that get linked against, but that did not solve this linking issue. I'm setting up a virtual machine to run Windows so I can examine this further, but in the meantime, this PR at least fixes the std::tolower issue.

Edit: To better facilitate fixing these issues, I created a Windows environment and did some debugging with Visual Studio 2017. In the process, I found numerous issues with trying to build and run on Windows, so now the latest image of this pull request reflects numerous fixes that were necessary in order to compile ignition-common on Windows and successfully run its tests.

values.description:
Before:


```
#!c++

caguero@bb20:~/workspace/ign-common$ sh tools/code_check.sh 
[include/ignition/common/EnumIface.hh:53]: (performance) Function parameter '_names' should be passed by reference.
[include/ignition/common/Event.hh:513]: (performance) Function parameter '_cb' should be passed by reference.
[include/ignition/common/PluginInfo.hh:48]: (style) struct member 'PluginInfo::baseClassHash' is never used.
[include/ignition/common/MovingWindowFilter.hh:68]: (style) 'class MovingWindowFilter' does not have a copy constructor which is recommended since the class contains a pointer to allocated memory.
[src/AudioDecoder.cc:106]: (style) Condition '!decodedFrame' is always true
Total errors found: 0
```

After:


```
#!c++

caguero@bb20:~/workspace/ign-common$ sh tools/code_check.sh 
Total errors found: 0
```
values.title: Fix all style checker issues

values.description: This PR integrates `ignition-common` with the first version of [ignition-cmake](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/1/).
values.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

summary.raw: This PR integrates `ignition-common` with the first version of [ignition-cmake](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/1/).
summary.html: This PR integrates ignition-common with the first version of ignition-cmake.

values.description:
fprintf() is considered to be an atomic output, while
using the stream operator (<<) is not.  Thus, using
the stream operator inside of the Console was sometimes
causing control characters to be put on different lines
than the rest of the string, leading to really ugly output.
By forming up the string into a stringstream and then using
fprintf(), we get rid of that particular issue.  Note that
this only improves, but doesn't completely solve the issue;
if the user of ignition::common::Console uses the stream
operator to concatenate individual strings, the same problem
can happen, but at least the control codes will not be
everywhere.
values.title: Switch to using fprintf in ignition Console.

summary.raw:
fprintf() is considered to be an atomic output, while
using the stream operator (<<) is not.  Thus, using
the stream operator inside of the Console was sometimes
causing control characters to be put on different lines
than the rest of the string, leading to really ugly output.
By forming up the string into a stringstream and then using
fprintf(), we get rid of that particular issue.  Note that
this only improves, but doesn't completely solve the issue;
if the user of ignition::common::Console uses the stream
operator to concatenate individual strings, the same problem
can happen, but at least the control codes will not be
everywhere.
summary.html: fprintf() is considered to be an atomic output, while using the stream operator (<<) is not. Thus, using the stream operator inside of the Console was sometimes causing control characters to be put on different lines than the rest of the string, leading to really ugly output. By forming up the string into a stringstream and then using fprintf(), we get rid of that particular issue. Note that this only improves, but doesn't completely solve the issue; if the user of ignition::common::Console uses the stream operator to concatenate individual strings, the same problem can happen, but at least the control codes will not be everywhere.

values.description:
This PR uses the [`Components` branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/2/) of ignition-cmake and modularizes the functionality of ignition-common as requested in issue #14.

The one thing that has not been modularized yet is the `Plugin` implementation, because I'd like to minimize the merge conflicts that we're going to deal with from the plugin framework changes.
values.title: [WIP] Splitting ignition-common into component libraries

summary.raw:
This PR uses the [`Components` branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/2/) of ignition-cmake and modularizes the functionality of ignition-common as requested in issue #14.

The one thing that has not been modularized yet is the `Plugin` implementation, because I'd like to minimize the merge conflicts that we're going to deal with from the plugin framework changes.
summary.html:
This PR uses the Components branch of ignition-cmake and modularizes the functionality of ignition-common as requested in issue #14.

The one thing that has not been modularized yet is the Plugin implementation, because I'd like to minimize the merge conflicts that we're going to deal with from the plugin framework changes.

values.reason: Declining this PR in favor of [102](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/102/)

values.description:
This is a reduced version of the Plugin Framework Pull Request #59.

This PR does not have the template specializations (which are needed for good performance) nor the `PluginPtr` class (which is needed for the template specializations). Since those were perhaps the most complex parts of the implementation, their removal might help the review process a little bit since reviewers can now focus their attention somewhat.

Ultimately, I expect the template specializations and `PluginPtr` to be merged in as well (unless we can come up with a nicer implementation that provides the same performance, but I don't currently believe that's possible, not that I would discourage anyone from trying).

Note that there are some vestigial functions in this pull request which aren't strictly needed in the absence of the template specialization, so that may cause some confusion during the review, but I'd prefer not to pollute the version history with too many redundant removals and insertions, so I'm going to leave them in unless reviewers would strongly prefer that they be taken out.

As a quick overview of what this PR specifically offers:

1. The plugin framework can now support arbitrarily many plugins per library, and arbitrarily many interface per plugin.

2. The `PluginLoader` class now returns a generic `PluginPtr` (in this PR the `PluginPtr` is a `std::shared_ptr<Plugin>`, but that will change in pull request #59). The generic `Plugin` object grants access to the interfaces provided by the plugin that was loaded.

3. Interfaces can be retrieved as `std::shared_ptr<T>` objects where `T` is one of the interfaces provided by the loaded plugin. This allows a user to simply query the `Plugin` for the specific interfaces that they want, and then discard the generic `PluginPtr` that was originally returned by the `PluginLoader`.
values.title: Slimmed down the Plugin pull request (no more template specializations)

Ultimately, I expect the template specializations and `PluginPtr` to be merged in as well (unless we can come up with a nicer implementation that provides the same performance, but I don't currently believe that's possible, not that I would discourage anyone from trying).

Note that there are some vestigial functions in this pull request which aren't strictly needed in the absence of the template specialization, so that may cause some confusion during the review, but I'd prefer not to pollute the version history with too many redundant removals and insertions, so I'm going to leave them in unless reviewers would strongly prefer that they be taken out.

As a quick overview of what this PR specifically offers:

1. The plugin framework can now support arbitrarily many plugins per library, and arbitrarily many interface per plugin.

2. The `PluginLoader` class now returns a generic `PluginPtr` (in this PR the `PluginPtr` is a `std::shared_ptr<Plugin>`, but that will change in pull request #59). The generic `Plugin` object grants access to the interfaces provided by the plugin that was loaded.

3. Interfaces can be retrieved as `std::shared_ptr<T>` objects where `T` is one of the interfaces provided by the loaded plugin. This allows a user to simply query the `Plugin` for the specific interfaces that they want, and then discard the generic `PluginPtr` that was originally returned by the `PluginLoader`.
summary.html:
This is a reduced version of the Plugin Framework Pull Request #59.

This PR does not have the template specializations (which are needed for good performance) nor the PluginPtr class (which is needed for the template specializations). Since those were perhaps the most complex parts of the implementation, their removal might help the review process a little bit since reviewers can now focus their attention somewhat.

Ultimately, I expect the template specializations and PluginPtr to be merged in as well (unless we can come up with a nicer implementation that provides the same performance, but I don't currently believe that's possible, not that I would discourage anyone from trying).

Note that there are some vestigial functions in this pull request which aren't strictly needed in the absence of the template specialization, so that may cause some confusion during the review, but I'd prefer not to pollute the version history with too many redundant removals and insertions, so I'm going to leave them in unless reviewers would strongly prefer that they be taken out.

As a quick overview of what this PR specifically offers:

  1. The plugin framework can now support arbitrarily many plugins per library, and arbitrarily many interface per plugin.

  2. The PluginLoader class now returns a generic PluginPtr (in this PR the PluginPtr is a std::shared_ptr<Plugin>, but that will change in pull request #59). The generic Plugin object grants access to the interfaces provided by the plugin that was loaded.

  3. Interfaces can be retrieved as std::shared_ptr<T> objects where T is one of the interfaces provided by the loaded plugin. This allows a user to simply query the Plugin for the specific interfaces that they want, and then discard the generic PluginPtr that was originally returned by the PluginLoader.

values.description:
Switch to ignition-math4 by default, with a fallback to ignition-math3 so we have a smooth transition for the homebrew formula and CI for other pull requests.

After this is merged, we will update CI to use ignition-math4 and then we can disable searching for ignition-math3.
values.title: Search for ign-math4 by default, fallback to 3

summary.raw:
Switch to ignition-math4 by default, with a fallback to ignition-math3 so we have a smooth transition for the homebrew formula and CI for other pull requests.

After this is merged, we will update CI to use ignition-math4 and then we can disable searching for ignition-math3.
summary.html:
Switch to ignition-math4 by default, with a fallback to ignition-math3 so we have a smooth transition for the homebrew formula and CI for other pull requests.

After this is merged, we will update CI to use ignition-math4 and then we can disable searching for ignition-math3.

values.description:
The homebrew build has some [compiler warnings and a test failure](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/72/). This makes it :blue_circle: [blue](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/96/).

* 443f810: [avcodec_decode_video2 is deprecated](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/7fc329e2dd6226dfecaa4a1d7adf353bf2773726), so fix deprecation warning by making a new function in ffmpeg_inc.cc that uses either that old function or the new method described in [this blog post](https://blogs.gentoo.org/lu_zero/2016/03/29/new-avcodec-api/)
* 372f92e: a struct parameter got deprecated, so add `ifdef`s with the old and new name
* 65af648: the codec context is not part of `AVStream` structure anymore, so allocate a new context according to their [documented example](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/bba6a03b2816d805d44bce4f9701a71f7d3f8dad). I re-ordered the existing code a little to match the example.
* 5d1fdc2: fix VideoEncoder_TEST (#24) by converting to `mpg` instead of `ogv` since the ffmpeg bottle on homebrew doesn't have `ogv` support (you have to build from source).
values.title: Fix brew compiler warnings and tests

summary.raw:
The homebrew build has some [compiler warnings and a test failure](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/72/). This makes it :blue_circle: [blue](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/96/).

* 443f810: [avcodec_decode_video2 is deprecated](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/7fc329e2dd6226dfecaa4a1d7adf353bf2773726), so fix deprecation warning by making a new function in ffmpeg_inc.cc that uses either that old function or the new method described in [this blog post](https://blogs.gentoo.org/lu_zero/2016/03/29/new-avcodec-api/)
* 372f92e: a struct parameter got deprecated, so add `ifdef`s with the old and new name
* 65af648: the codec context is not part of `AVStream` structure anymore, so allocate a new context according to their [documented example](https://github.com/FFmpeg/FFmpeg/commit/bba6a03b2816d805d44bce4f9701a71f7d3f8dad). I re-ordered the existing code a little to match the example.
* 5d1fdc2: fix VideoEncoder_TEST (#24) by converting to `mpg` instead of `ogv` since the ffmpeg bottle on homebrew doesn't have `ogv` support (you have to build from source).
summary.html:
The homebrew build has some compiler warnings and a test failure. This makes it blue.

  • 443f810: avcodec_decode_video2 is deprecated, so fix deprecation warning by making a new function in ffmpeg_inc.cc that uses either that old function or the new method described in this blog post
  • 372f92e: a struct parameter got deprecated, so add ifdefs with the old and new name
  • 65af648: the codec context is not part of AVStream structure anymore, so allocate a new context according to their documented example. I re-ordered the existing code a little to match the example.
  • 5d1fdc2: fix VideoEncoder_TEST (#24) by converting to mpg instead of ogv since the ffmpeg bottle on homebrew doesn't have ogv support (you have to build from source).

values.description:
This is the `ign-common` PR that relates to [the `release-tools` proposal](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/463/).

This depends on the `CMakeRefactor-default-WindowsUpdate-Oct2017` branch of `ign-math`, which in turn depends on the `WindowsUpdate-Oct2017` branch of `ign-cmake`. Note that these dependencies are encoded in each of the branches instead of being something that needs to be set in `release-tools`.
values.title: Proposal: Updating to Visual Studio 2017 and improving Windows CI

values.description:
The ign-common prerelease bottle builds succeeded but compiling example code against the bottles failed due to a windows-only header being included in common.hh. So I've added example compilation to the pipeline, which reproduced the windows header failure in 16750de. Excluding the windows header from common.hh fixed the build.

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder-highsierra/81/

We'll need another prerelease after this to fix `common.hh`.
values.title: Compile examples in pipeline, fix common.hh

summary.raw:
The ign-common prerelease bottle builds succeeded but compiling example code against the bottles failed due to a windows-only header being included in common.hh. So I've added example compilation to the pipeline, which reproduced the windows header failure in 16750de. Excluding the windows header from common.hh fixed the build.

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder-highsierra/81/

We'll need another prerelease after this to fix `common.hh`.
summary.html:
The ign-common prerelease bottle builds succeeded but compiling example code against the bottles failed due to a windows-only header being included in common.hh. So I've added example compilation to the pipeline, which reproduced the windows header failure in 16750de. Excluding the windows header from common.hh fixed the build.

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/os_homebrew/job/generic-release-homebrew_bottle_builder-highsierra/81/

We'll need another prerelease after this to fix common.hh.

values.description:
tinyxml2 version 6.0.0 was just released into homebrew with some API breakages without a tick-tock, which has [broken the homebrew build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/BuildCopFail/job/ignition_common-ci-default-homebrew-amd64/89/). I've added some compiler directives here to handle the change, but I had to define an extra macro with cmake in our generated config.hh. I think this cmake variable only works if tinyxml2 is found using `pkg_check_modules`. They do have the version defined in the tinyxml2.h header file, but the numbers are `static const int`s, which can't be evaluated in compiler directives.

I shared some feedback with the maintainer of tinyxml2 about the migration challenges this API change has caused:

* https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/issues/635
values.title: Support new ErrorStr API in tinyxml2 6.0.0 (#28)

I've added some compiler directives here to handle the change, but I had to define an extra macro with cmake in our generated config.hh. I think this cmake variable only works if tinyxml2 is found using `pkg_check_modules`. They do have the version defined in the tinyxml2.h header file, but the numbers are `static const int`s, which can't be evaluated in compiler directives.

I shared some feedback with the maintainer of tinyxml2 about the migration challenges this API change has caused:

* https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/issues/635
summary.html:
tinyxml2 version 6.0.0 was just released into homebrew with some API breakages without a tick-tock, which has broken the homebrew build. I've added some compiler directives here to handle the change, but I had to define an extra macro with cmake in our generated config.hh. I think this cmake variable only works if tinyxml2 is found using pkg_check_modules. They do have the version defined in the tinyxml2.h header file, but the numbers are static const ints, which can't be evaluated in compiler directives.

I shared some feedback with the maintainer of tinyxml2 about the migration challenges this API change has caused:

  • https://github.com/leethomason/tinyxml2/issues/635

values.title: Fixversion 1 name and examples

values.description:
This pull request build on pull request #59 by introducing a concrete example of how the plugin framework can be used.

The current example accepts two different types of plugins:

1. A numerical integration plugin
2. A system of differential equations plugin

The example will accept a list of libraries that provide one or both of these plugin types, and then test each integrator against each system of differential equations, and provide test results that allow the user to compare the performance of each integration method.

I'm creating this as a separate pull request to make it easier to provide feedback on this example, and to give us a place to brainstorm ideas for additional examples.

This first example uses two different plugin types where each type of plugin provides a single interface. Ideally, I'd like to come up with an example where a single plugin instance may be able to provide multiple interfaces, along with the possibility that some of those interfaces are optional. If anyone has ideas for an example that would illustrate that, I would appreciate any and all input.

----

Edit: I've added one more example, which can be found in `robot.cc`. It performs a lightweight 2D "simulation" of a robot which is given as a plugin. The environment consists of a set of walls (defined by pairs of points) and is generated by a second plugin.

The robot plugin has one mandatory interface (`Drive`) and a set of optional interfaces (`ProximitySensor`, `GPSSensor`, `Compass`, and `MapDatabase`), all defined in `robot.hh`, which is a header shared by all the robot plugins.
values.title: Examples for using plugins

summary.raw:
This pull request build on pull request #59 by introducing a concrete example of how the plugin framework can be used.

The current example accepts two different types of plugins:

1. A numerical integration plugin
2. A system of differential equations plugin

The example will accept a list of libraries that provide one or both of these plugin types, and then test each integrator against each system of differential equations, and provide test results that allow the user to compare the performance of each integration method.

I'm creating this as a separate pull request to make it easier to provide feedback on this example, and to give us a place to brainstorm ideas for additional examples.

This first example uses two different plugin types where each type of plugin provides a single interface. Ideally, I'd like to come up with an example where a single plugin instance may be able to provide multiple interfaces, along with the possibility that some of those interfaces are optional. If anyone has ideas for an example that would illustrate that, I would appreciate any and all input.

----

Edit: I've added one more example, which can be found in `robot.cc`. It performs a lightweight 2D "simulation" of a robot which is given as a plugin. The environment consists of a set of walls (defined by pairs of points) and is generated by a second plugin.

The robot plugin has one mandatory interface (`Drive`) and a set of optional interfaces (`ProximitySensor`, `GPSSensor`, `Compass`, and `MapDatabase`), all defined in `robot.hh`, which is a header shared by all the robot plugins.
summary.html:
This pull request build on pull request #59 by introducing a concrete example of how the plugin framework can be used.

The current example accepts two different types of plugins:

  1. A numerical integration plugin
  2. A system of differential equations plugin

The example will accept a list of libraries that provide one or both of these plugin types, and then test each integrator against each system of differential equations, and provide test results that allow the user to compare the performance of each integration method.

I'm creating this as a separate pull request to make it easier to provide feedback on this example, and to give us a place to brainstorm ideas for additional examples.

This first example uses two different plugin types where each type of plugin provides a single interface. Ideally, I'd like to come up with an example where a single plugin instance may be able to provide multiple interfaces, along with the possibility that some of those interfaces are optional. If anyone has ideas for an example that would illustrate that, I would appreciate any and all input.

Edit: I've added one more example, which can be found in robot.cc. It performs a lightweight 2D "simulation" of a robot which is given as a plugin. The environment consists of a set of walls (defined by pairs of points) and is generated by a second plugin.

The robot plugin has one mandatory interface (Drive) and a set of optional interfaces (ProximitySensor, GPSSensor, Compass, and MapDatabase), all defined in robot.hh, which is a header shared by all the robot plugins.

values.reason: This PR will transition over to the upcoming `ign-plugin` repo.

values.description:
The Base64 class had 28% coverage; this increases it to 100%.

* add Base64 unit test that checks which characters are produced by Encode and verifies that Decode recovers the original

* document that encoded Base64 string is terminated with '=' character

values.description: Add braces around `EXPECT_*` statements in if blocks, since `EXPECT_*` are macros and cause a [dangling else warning with gcc7 on artful](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-ign-common1-artful-amd64/1/warningsResult/).
values.title: Fix gcc7 compiler warnings on artful

summary.raw: Add braces around `EXPECT_*` statements in if blocks, since `EXPECT_*` are macros and cause a [dangling else warning with gcc7 on artful](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-ign-common1-artful-amd64/1/warningsResult/).
summary.html: Add braces around EXPECT_* statements in if blocks, since EXPECT_* are macros and cause a dangling else warning with gcc7 on artful.

values.description:
This pull request introduces numerous quality of life improvements for users, as well as improvements to robustness, type safety, comprehensiveness of the library, and forward compatibility with possible future revisions of the library. I'll break down the description into quality of life, type safety, and forward compatibility:

## Quality of life

Up until now, there have been some onerous restrictions on how and where a user must register a plugin. The following restrictions are **no longer** required, as of this PR:

1. All plugins must be registered in one translation unit (now you can register across arbitrarily many translation units)
1. All plugins must be registered in one block which is enclosed by `IGN_COMMON_BEGIN_ADDING_PLUGINS` and `IGN_COMMON_FINISH_ADDING_PLUGINS` (those macros are no longer needed, ever)
1. Each interface must be registered in a separate macro (the macros are now variadic, so you can specify a list of interfaces all at once).
1. All plugins must be registered in the global namespace (the macro can be called in any namespace now)

## Type Safety

We have eliminated all use of strings when referring to interfaces (except where it provides tangible value to do so, like asking for meta-information about some interface). Plugin pointer specializations can be used with all interface types, without needing to put a macro into the interface class.

Most importantly, we can now robustly handle plugin classes and plugin interfaces that are defined by templates. There are no limitations to what kinds of classes can be used as interfaces or plugin classes (except that the plugin class needs to be fully concrete, but that requirement is a given).

This template support is crucial for the upcoming "feature system" concept of `ign-physics`.

## Forward Compatibility

The hook for extracting plugins from a library now has a handshake routine where the loader and the loadee can communicate with each other about what versions they expect. This will allow us to add additional features in the future while perfectly continuing to support older versions, both for loading plugins and for being loaded.

Ironically, this will intentionally break compatibility with previous versions, but I think now is the ideal time to do so, since the use of this plugin library is still predominantly internal.
values.title: Better plugin registration

summary.html:
This pull request introduces numerous quality of life improvements for users, as well as improvements to robustness, type safety, comprehensiveness of the library, and forward compatibility with possible future revisions of the library. I'll break down the description into quality of life, type safety, and forward compatibility:

Quality of life

Up until now, there have been some onerous restrictions on how and where a user must register a plugin. The following restrictions are no longer required, as of this PR:

  1. All plugins must be registered in one translation unit (now you can register across arbitrarily many translation units)
  2. All plugins must be registered in one block which is enclosed by IGN_COMMON_BEGIN_ADDING_PLUGINS and IGN_COMMON_FINISH_ADDING_PLUGINS (those macros are no longer needed, ever)
  3. Each interface must be registered in a separate macro (the macros are now variadic, so you can specify a list of interfaces all at once).
  4. All plugins must be registered in the global namespace (the macro can be called in any namespace now)

Type Safety

We have eliminated all use of strings when referring to interfaces (except where it provides tangible value to do so, like asking for meta-information about some interface). Plugin pointer specializations can be used with all interface types, without needing to put a macro into the interface class.

Most importantly, we can now robustly handle plugin classes and plugin interfaces that are defined by templates. There are no limitations to what kinds of classes can be used as interfaces or plugin classes (except that the plugin class needs to be fully concrete, but that requirement is a given).

This template support is crucial for the upcoming "feature system" concept of ign-physics.

Forward Compatibility

The hook for extracting plugins from a library now has a handshake routine where the loader and the loadee can communicate with each other about what versions they expect. This will allow us to add additional features in the future while perfectly continuing to support older versions, both for loading plugins and for being loaded.

Ironically, this will intentionally break compatibility with previous versions, but I think now is the ideal time to do so, since the use of this plugin library is still predominantly internal.

values.description:
[default branch build on artful](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-default-artful-amd64/1/) is :yellow_heart: due to compiler warnings (pull request #97) and cppcheck (this branch)

[this branch](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-artful-amd64/1/) is :blue_circle:

I grouped the changes by commit.

* fix defines in code_check script

* move ifdef's to fix variable scope

* remove redundant variable assignments

* adjust inline suppressions
values.title: Fix artful cppcheck

values.description:
I was tracking an issue related with plotting and while debugging I found a problem here.

There was an extra `0` in the `IGN_NANO_TO_SEC` macro. This bug was affecting the functions `Double()` and `Float()`.
values.title: Fix nanosecond to second conversion
